Author: lord kek#0511
Content: I'm not sure I understand why you would feel uncomfortable with me saying it has changed or rather how it can be seen as loaded statement. It seems to be key aspect of the PirateChain, it's mentioned many times in the site. If a project puts out new ways to achieve something, isn't it quite healthy for everybody that people are interested in these changes?

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: but I guess I got what I came for. Your take on the subject. I have no stake in the success of PirateChain or dPoW and I gain nothing if it turns out to not be good idea.

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: I don't see my self going to broadcast my views on this to all my 17 followers to sabotage anybodys project, this one included.

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: But thank you for the answers. Good luck with what you're doing everybody.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you asked, I answered. I tried to be clear

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: sure, your answer is appreciated.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you find any change to the game theory that is a negative change, let us know

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: Who controls these notary nodes tho?

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: You would need to update the notary nodes to be able to hard fork the chain I would assume?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notaries control their own nodes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notaries are elected by the KMD stake

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: hard fork what chain?

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: The pirateChain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notaries are updating their nodes as everybody else is

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: entire community is updating

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: hmm

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: so is the assumption here that the community agrees?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with all hard forks that is the assumption

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: I don't think that's accurate

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if for whatever reason the notaries didnt update, then they would generate invalid notarizations that will just be ignored

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: for example segwit2x would be good example of this

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in a hard fork, if you dont update, you get left behind

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you dont update to what the community decides

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i am not clear on what community segwit2x ever had, or what actual nodes. didnt everyone just abandon it other than a few scammers?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you are using such an outlier case to say that what? the community didnt agree to hardfork to the next bitcoin ?

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: they had overwhelming support of industry actors and I think hash rate too, but the fork was abandoned still

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: industry actors?

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: exchanges, companies such

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how many people ran segwit2x?

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: that's hard to know, because it's basically just signaling and it doesn't mean anything before the fork, because it doesn't tie you into anything

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: but I mentioned this only to demonstrate that it's assumed that the community agrees on hard forks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in a normal non-politicized hardfork, the community just updates

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: yeah, those are easy

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: let us agree that btc hardforks cant even agree on changing a maxblocksize #define after 4 years, so any meaningful change is impossible without massive controversy

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: at komodo, we are a bit more efficient than that

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: I'm just trying to figure out if there's a component of increased centralization as a tradeoff for the rather clever way to gain additional protection to the "native" hash rate of the chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all nodes validate all notarizations

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that makes it very decentralized

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just like all nodes validate all transactions

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notaries are not master nodes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: they are not delegates that create blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: they have very small powers

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: to make valid notarizations

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: so basically if "PirateChain SV" wanted to hard fork to what ever ruleset, these nodes would not get stuck if the notaries  didn't notarize the new ruleset?

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: they would just operate as if there are no notaries and rely on what ever hashrate the new "SV chain" has?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: correct

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notarization is not controlling block production

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is just a transaction that is containing notarization data

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: which happens to be used by all nodes to update their notarization state, if it is a valid notarization

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: could someone block this "SV chain" from gaining this notarization?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notarization is a service

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notaries would need to optin to offering the notarizations

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: Hmm

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: having the notarization being there or not, would go a long way toward removing market confusion as to which is the real PIRATE chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in any case SV and ABC were different chains the moment of chain split as they had blocks with different rulesets

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there was no winner take all hashwar at all

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there was always going to be two separate chains

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just without replay protection at the tx level, it made it very risky to use either

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: that fork was indeed weird occurrence, it effectively resulted in 3 chains

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: even in this insane scenario. if it were replicated with PIRATE, the community would know which PIRATE was being notarized and likely the other chain wouldnt get much traction

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: of course if both chains were to get notarization, then it would be clear that there would be two chains,but we wouldnt notarize a new fork that didnt have replay protection

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: You don't see that as aspect of centralization? To me it seems these notaries are a player with real power. Even if them picking sides doesn't mean the "other side" (the one without notarization) wouldn't be able to run without the support of notaries, you say they have weight when the "legit" chain is "chosen". And to be clear, I'm not saying that tradeoff would necessarily be bad. I can see it being beneficial even if it came with a cost in form of lesser decree of decentralization

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notaries help decide which is the real chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it uses a stochastic distributed consensus method that no single node controls

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notarizations are validated by all nodes, making the complete process decentralized

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: now in politicized chain split scenarios where central actors are already at play, sure, the notarization provides another reference point

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: since in a a politicized scenario, it has little to do with technology, consensus protocols, etc. it seems moot the effect of having or not having notarization has on the process.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: in that case, would not the other side just deploy their own notaries? Or thats what I would do if it was me.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it can be argued either way, that notarization is helping or hurting the chain split resolution, depending on your politics of the situation. This has nothing to do with the chain consensus. It is as relevant as to whether a node operators prefer McDonalds or Burger King

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this has nothing to do with dPoW

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it can be discussed in #fastfood

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: sure, but if they chose Burger King, community would likely be rooting for Burger King, because the notaries help determine which one the brave sailors are to consume if they want to sail the "correct" ship. I'm sure the Burger King side of the community would appreciate this

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: regardless, such aspects are not part of non-politicized dPoW analysis

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: hmm

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and PIRATESV would just make their own notaries claiming that they only eat vegetarian so are better notaries

Author: Gordon Komodo#7477
Content: sv chain can be notarized if they pay the fee? , so both chains can do whatever they want üòÑ

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: if its worth it to notarise some forked chain, you can notarise it...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the bottom line is that dPoW does not need to be perfect

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it just needs to be better than not having it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if so, then it is worth having

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and personally I wouldnt touch a chain without dPoW or a very high hashrate

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe some PoS chains are not so bad, depending on the genesis details

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: I'm not sure I would phrase it like that. I'm not sure it's so easy to determine what is better. What I mean is, it's not as easy as looking at a number and seeing one is bigger, hence it's better. Most times these are not about being objectively better, it's about tradeoffs and which ones you're willing to make, what you value most

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: It seems pretty easy to me to decide that having a chain being able to be reorged 300+ blocks vs one that lets you know when it is notarized or not and not being able to be reorged much at all

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you want a number, use the max reorg depth

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: or the amount of funds at risk of 51% attack

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you are ok with deep reorgs and big money lost from 51% attack, then great, dPoW isnt for you

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if however you are ok with the type of fastfood notary operators eat, to avoid deep reorgs and 51% attacks, then dPoW should be considered

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: sure, if you are restricted to one metric. Say you were willing to run master nodes, you don't have to burn electricity, you can scale way easier, but it's not like there is no cost. You might see it as cost worth paying, but I don't think it's so simple

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: dPoW is much much much less centralizing than masternodes, which is less that dPoS

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: it was not a comparison, it was an attempt to demonstrate that there are many "numbers" to look at when determining what's better

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: and what's better is not always simple, because it depends on the tradeoffs you are willing to make and how you value these. I don't think every coin or token needs to be "better bitcoin" I can see the crypto landscape where different projects have different tradeoffs. Right tool for the job type of thing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this is why we dont expect 100% of coins to adopt dPoW

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we never said taht

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: I'm sorry, I have to ask, do you feel I'm adversarial here?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we do say that for a chain without a lot of hashrate, having dPoW offers a lot of protection with minimal downside

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: are you adversarial?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I just stated that we dont expect all coins to adopt dPoW

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: that's not my intention at least

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in response to your "right tool for the job" post
